instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01958: What is 820-01958? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.3V3_G3H_RTC: What is 3V3_G3H_RTC? 3V3_G3H_RTC Is an abbreviation of PP3V3_G3H_RTC which is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not coming up
threads.message:
The board came in dead, no corrosion
The ammeter shows 5v and restarts
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>=12.32 but pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>=3.3v pulsing also
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL>=not present
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_G3S</SIGNAL> is short sometimes it's not
I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q8270</TRANSISTOR> after I found out its getting hot on thermal camera still the ammeter shows 5v and restart

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not coming up
threads.message:
Check diode mode to ground and voltage pulse on other coils too.

Tried DFU?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not coming up
threads.message:
The board did not enter DFU
L7670 pin1=0.419,pin2=0.418
0.019volts
L7690 pin1=0.386,pin2=0.386
3.3volts not stable
L7030 pin1=0.444,pin2=0.444
5.0volts not stable

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not coming up
threads.message:
What's the reason to check both pins of a coil?
Do you really expect to get different values???
Put some logic and save time on your job.

So no pulse at L7670?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not coming up
threads.message: No pulse at L7670 with 0.039 volts

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not coming up
threads.message: What happens connecting known good battery?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not coming up
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not coming up
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> still pulsing with battery connected?
Don't you get stable <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> and <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> voltages?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not coming up
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is stable when battery is connected but restarts when the ammeter restart and 
<SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> is stable but restart when the ammeter restart and <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> voltages too

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A not coming up
threads.message:
Test the board alone on the desk; nothing connected apart of charger.

Check diode mode to ground and voltage pulse on ALL board's coils.
